isis.stitle: BRAKE COMPONENTS: This Service Manual Section should be used for reference only. For more current service information on all components go to the Bendix website from the ISIS Suppliers menu and refer to the Service Data Sheets. - AIR DRYER - CR BRAKEMASTER MODEL 62

svcsubproc.title: Description
svcsubproc.para: When the compressed air leaves the air compressor, it is approximately 300°F (149°C), and by the time it reaches the Brakemaster unit, it has cooled to 140°F (60°C).
The hot, compressed air enters the expansion chamber where the sudden drop in pressure provides additional cooling. Heat is dissipated through the external fins on the one-piece aluminum body.

As the air cools in the expansion chamber, both water and oil vapors are condensed. This condensation collects on the walls of the expansion chamber and runs down into the collection area where it is automatically discharged through an unloader valve.

The heat exchanger has a permanent air filter element which traps carbon particles harmful to other components in the air system. Each time the unloader operates (each time the compressor completes a cycle), there is a back-rush of air through the filter, so that any carbon trapped in the filter element is flushed out and ejected through the unloader valve.
If the air compressor is working properly, the filter will require little or no maintenance. If the filter should require servicing, flush it with cleaning solvent and air dry.

svcsubproc.title: Maintenance
svcsubproc.para: Periodic or scheduled maintenance is not required. However, for trouble-free operation, the following items should be checked.

step1.para: Cooling fins should be free of dirt build-up or paint.
Check air lines to be sure they have not become kinked, cracked, broken or chafed.
Build up pressure in air system, then bleed off air to cause the compressor to cycle. Repeat several times.
Compare heat level inlet and outlet ports by holding your hands on each of the ports.

warning.para: The inlet port may be hot; a burn could result if touched.

svcsubproc.title: Service Checks
svcsubproc.para: The inlet port should be warmer than the outlet port; the outlet port should be at or slightly above ambient temperature. Since the vehicle is stationary, the unit will become warmer than normally experienced during over the road operation. If both inlet and outlet temperatures seem high (too hot to touch), the deflector will need servicing.

step1.para: Hold a clean shop towel under the unloader (exhaust) port and make the air compressor go through several "unload" cycles. Catch water from the unloader port. If water is oily, the compressor should be checked. If water is "brownish" or if brown particles are expelled, the deflector requires servicing.

After the heat exchanger has "exhausted" and while air compressor is in "stand-by" mode, hold your hand under the unloader port. If air flows out the port, the check valve at the top (outlet port) of the heat exchanger is stuck open and requires service, or the compressor inlet is connected to the outlet side of the turbocharger.
If air leaks past the exhaust port while the compressor is building up pressure, the unloader valve is stuck open and requires attention.
While the air compressor is building up pressure, it is normal for the check valve to produce a rattling sound through rapid opening and closing.
When the air compressor is rebuilt or replaced or if the heat exchanger is moved from one vehicle to another, it is recommended that the heat exchanger unit be completely disassembled and cleaned.

svcsubproc.para: If the unloader valve should stick in the open position while the vehicle is on the road, the air system can be restored by threading a 1/2 inch pipe plug into the exhaust port. By doing this, the air system pressure can be restored but moisture cannot be exhausted from the air dryer. The unit should be serviced as soon as possible by repairing the unloader valve.
Before any work is accomplished, it is important to check the following:

step1.para: The area surrounding the unit, and the unit itself, should be thoroughly cleaned to remove dirt, oil and other road grime.
Set parking brake and block wheels.
Drain all air from vehicle's air system.
Relieve pressure in line from "UNL" port of compressor governor to unloader port in the center of the large nut on the bottom of the air dryer.

svcsubproc.para: Each part of the heat exchanger can be serviced by means of using the various service and replacement kits available.

svcsubproc.title: Unloader Valve Service
svcsubproc.para: There are several indications which may mean that the unloader valve of your heat exchanger unit needs servicing:

step1.para: The compressor goes into "stand-by" mode but cycles rapidly.
Air flows from the exhaust port when the compressor is attempting to build up pressure in the air system.
The unit does not "unload" when the compressor goes into stand-by mode.

svcsubproc.para:
These situations can be caused by several conditions. Check the
TROUBLESHOOTING CHART
, to make sure that the probable cause is a malfunctioning unloader valve on the CR BRAKEMASTER unit. If the probable cause is the unloader valve, it could mean that a piece of debris is clogging this valve, and it only needs to be cleaned, or that the valve assembly itself has been worn and needs to be replaced. In either case, the following steps should be taken:

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 61 for all items in parentheses.

figure.caption: Figure 61. Air Dryer - CR Brakemaster Model 62

step1.para: Disconnect electrical wire to heater.
Disconnect inlet air line from bottom cap (Item 29).
Remove governor control line from UNL port (Item 26).
Remove large unloader nut (Item 27) from UNL port (Item 26).

warning.para: Use care in removing the nut to prevent bodily injury since nut is spring loaded.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 62 for items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para: Remove complete unloader valve assembly, including copper gaskets (Item 10).

svcsubproc.para: Excessive accumulation of oil in the unloader assembly indicates that the air compressor requires attention.

step1.para: Examine unloader valve assembly. If the unloader sleeve (Item 5) is nicked, wrinkled or has axial scratches, the unloader valve assembly should be replaced. If clogged, the unloader valve assembly should be cleaned with a good cleansing solvent.
Do not remove retaining ring (Item 7) from unloader spindle (Item 9) since they are serviced as an assembly with spring (Item 8) and ring seat (Item 1).

svcsubproc.title: Reassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 62 for items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para: Install new "U" cup (Item 3) in groove of unloader piston (Item 6). Lips of "U" cup should face away from spring seat. Do not use sharp tools that may mar or score parts.
Apply a light film of Fleetrite EP2 Moly grease or equivalent to NLGI#2 multi-purpose lithium grease to O-ring (Item 4) and position on unloader nut.

Position the two copper gaskets (Item 10) together and lightly coat exposed surfaces with Fleetrite EP2 Moly grease or equivalent to NLGI#2 multi-purpose lithium grease. Then position lubricated gaskets on shoulder of ring seat (Item 1). Gaskets should be on face opposite the spring (Item 8).
Install unloader sleeve (Item 5) in unloader port against the ring seat. Be sure the 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) diameter cross hole is next to the ring seat (Item 1).
Position large spring (Item 2) in the sleeve (Item 5) with large diameter coil against ring seat (Item 1).

Insert unloader piston (Item 6) into unloader sleeve. Lips of U-cup (Item 3) must face out with spring seat toward spring. The unloader spindle (Item 9) and ring seat (Item 1) is a mated assembly and should not be disassembled. If either the ring seat or spindle is nicked, the entire mated assembly must be replaced as an assembly.

Apply a non-hardening sealing compound to threads in the unloader valve nut (Item 27, Figure 61 ) and install nut. Tighten nut to 60 ft-lbs. (81 N· m) - DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN- maintaining the alignment of the cross holes of sleeve (Item 28, Figure 61 ).

caution.para: Over-tightening of the unloader nut will result in damage to the unloader assembly.

step1.para: Remove the alignment rod inserted in Step 8.
Reinstall air inlet line from the compressor.
Connect electrical lead for the heater.

Test unit using the instructions listed in
MAINTENANCE
.

svcsubproc.title: Deflector Assembly Service
svcsubproc.para: There are several indications which may mean that the deflector assembly needs servicing:

step1.para: Compressed air is not sufficiently cooled.
Water exhausted by the CR BRAKEMASTER is brownish or brown particles are exhausted.
A piece of the deflector is caught in the unloader valve assembly, causing it not to operate properly.

svcsubproc.para:
These situations can be caused by several conditions. Check the
TROUBLESHOOTING CHART
, to make sure that the probable cause is a malfunctioning deflector assembly. If it is a malfunctioning deflector assembly, the following are the instructions for replacing this deflector assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 61 for all items in parentheses.

step1.para: Disconnect air compressor inlet line at UNL port (Item 26).
Disconnect wire from heater assembly.
Remove the eight capscrews (Item 13) retaining bottom cap (Item 29) to body (Item 33).
Remove bottom cap (Item 29) and deflector assembly (Item 34).
Remove all traces of old gasket(s) material from gasket surfaces of bottom cap (Item 29) and body. Discard old gaskets. Be careful not to scratch or mar new gasket surfaces.
Wash bottom cap (Item 29) and inside of unit with cleaning solvent.
Position new gasket (Item 31) on top of the surface of the deflector support plate (Item 32).
Position second new gasket (Item 30) on gasket surface of bottom cap.
Align bolt holes and position assembly against bottom gasket surface of body (Item 33). Use of gasket sealant is NOT recommended.
Insert eight capscrews (Item 13) to attach bottom cap to body and deflector assembly (Item 34). Tighten alternately to 15 ft-lbs. (20.3 N· m).
Reconnect the air line to the inlet port (this line leads from the compressor service port).
Reconnect the wire to the heater.

svcsubproc.title: Check Valve Assembly Service
svcsubproc.para: There are several indications which may mean that the check valve needs servicing:

step1.para: Air is exhausted from the exhaust port when compressor is in stand-by mode.
System air pressure bleeds off rapidly when air-using equipment is not being operated.
Compressor goes into stand-by mode but cycles rapidly.
Compressor attempts to build pressure but system pressure will not build up.
Safety valve opens.

svcsubproc.para:
These situations can be caused by several conditions. Check the
TROUBLESHOOTING CHART
, to make sure that the probable cause is a defective assembly. The following is the procedure for servicing and replacing the check valve assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 63 for all items in parentheses.

figure.caption: Figure 63. Air Dryer CR Brakemaster Model 62 - Disconnect Air Line

step1.para: Disconnect air line at outlet port at top of unit.
Remove top nut (Item 4). This nut is spring loaded.
Remove copper gaskets (Item 3), spring (Item 1), and check valve spindle (Item 2).
Clean and dry entire check valve area and top nut (Item 4).

svcsubproc.title: Reassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 63 for all items in parentheses.

step1.para: Position new check valve spindle (Item 2) in top cap with tapered end down.
Install spring (Item 1) in check valve spindle.
Position new copper gaskets (Item 3) in nut (Item 4) and rub a small quantity of grease on the gaskets to help them keep their position in the top nut.
Thread nut (Item 5) onto top cap studs and tighten to 15 ft-lbs. (20.3 N· m). Top nut (Item 4) is not included in check valve replacement kit.

Reconnect the air line to the outlet port. The safety valve cannot be serviced and it is recommended that it not be removed from the top cap. If the safety valve has been removed, apply non-hardening sealant to threads of top cap.

svcsubproc.title: Filter Assembly Service
svcsubproc.para: Although the filter assembly of the unit is designed to require little or no servicing, it is a good practice to service the filter assembly when performing service on other filters located on the vehicle. This servicing can be accomplished in one of two ways, either replacing entire filter assembly, or by servicing filter assembly. In most cases, only servicing will be necessary. The following are the steps for servicing the filter assembly.

svcsubproc.title: Disassemble
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 61 for all items in parentheses.

step1.para: Remove air line at outlet port (Item 1).
Remove eight capscrews holding top cap (Item 3) in body.

warning.para: The top cap is spring loaded to approximately 40 ft-lbs. (54 N S m). Use care in removing the top cap bolts to prevent possible bodily injury.

step1.para: Remove spring (Item 39).
Remove all traces of gasket material from top cap and body gasket surfaces (Items 40 and 43). Discard gasket. Be careful not to scratch or score gasket surfaces. Wash top cap in cleaning solvent.
Remove complete filter assembly.
Remove rubber packing ring (Item 36) and discard.

Discard old stainless steel filter (Item 38). If you are replacing the entire filter assembly, discard the entire filter assembly including filter cup (Item 5), strainer (Item 6) and V-spring (Item 2).
Wash strainer (Item 6) and filter cup (Item 5) in cleaning solvent.
Assemble stainless steel filter (Item 38) in filter cup (Item 5). Filter should be stretched slightly to fill the space in filter cup.
Reinstall strainer (Item 6) with flat face of strainer towards stainless steel filter.
Install V-spring (Item 2) holding the filter assembly together.
Install new packing ring (Item 36) on ledge of body.
Position filter assembly into body with large end down. The filter must set on packing ring.
Install heavy spring (Item 39) with larger diameter coil against top of filter assembly.
Position new gasket (Item 40) on body. Do not use gasket cement.
Position top cap (Item 3) and V-spring (Item 2) so that the small diameter coil on spring fits groove in top cap.

Compress spring and install four 3/8 capscrews (Item 4) into body. Each of these four screws should be engaged at least three full turns before load on cap is removed. Capscrews should be equally spaced. Then thread remaining screws into place.
Alternately tighten top cap bolts to 15 ft-lbs. (20.3 N· m).
Reconnect air line to outlet port.

svcsubproc.title: Thermostatically Controlled Cartridge Type Heater Service
svcsubproc.para: The current heat exchanger units contain a 15 volt 50 watt heater as standard equipment. This heater requires a newly designed bottom cap which is completely interchangeable with those in use previously. Use of this new cap may, however, necessitate a change of the deflector assembly if your present bottom cap has the deflector attached by screws.
There are two kits used in servicing the thermostatically controlled cartridge type heater assembly. Both heaters are 50 watt; however, one is 12 volt and the other is a 24 volt.

step1.para: Disconnect the electrical line from the heater.
Remove old cartridge type heater by loosening set screw for heater on bottom cap.
Remove old thermostat from bottom cap by removing the two small screws which retain the thermostat to the bottom cap. Discard entire heater/thermostat assembly.
Install new heater by inserting it into hole from which old heater was removed and tighten set screw.
Install new thermostat by inserting it into the hole from which old thermostat was removed and attach by means of the two screws provided.
Attach the lead from the thermostat to the electrical system. Even though the heater is thermostatically controlled, it is recommended that the heater be hooked up through a control switch.
Be sure the unit is grounded to the chassis.
